metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Calculations of percentage yield and atom economy of single-step or overall reaction pathways, and the advantages for society and for industry of developing chemical processes with a high atom economy

percentage_yield_definition.name: Percentage Yield Definition
percentage_yield_definition.correct: Percentage yield compares the actual amount of product obtained to the maximum possible (theoretical) amount, expressed as a percentage.

atom economy.error: Yield and atom economy are different measures.
atom economy.fix: Yield measures how much product you GOT. Atom economy measures how much of reactants BECOME product.
atom economy.action: Yield = what you obtained vs what was possible. Atom economy = efficiency of atom use.

reaction rate.error: Rate is how fast, yield is how much.
reaction rate.fix: Rate = speed of reaction. Yield = amount of product obtained vs theoretical maximum.
reaction rate.action: A fast reaction can still have low yield. Don't confuse speed with efficiency.

equilibrium constant.error: K measures position of equilibrium, not yield.
equilibrium constant.fix: K tells you the ratio of products to reactants at equilibrium. Yield tells you what you actually obtained.
equilibrium constant.action: K predicts what COULD happen. Yield measures what DID happen.

persistent.gap: You're confusing yield with other reaction measures.
persistent.action: Write definitions: yield = actual/theoretical, rate = speed, K = equilibrium ratio.

theoretical_yield.name: Theoretical Yield
theoretical_yield.formula: Calculated from stoichiometry using limiting reagent
theoretical_yield.correct: Theoretical yield is the maximum amount of product possible if all of the limiting reagent is converted to product, calculated using stoichiometry.

the amount you actually get.error: That's actual yield, not theoretical yield.
the amount you actually get.fix: Theoretical = maximum possible (calculated). Actual = what you really obtained (measured).
the amount you actually get.action: Theoretical is the ideal. Actual is reality. Reality is always ≤ ideal.

the mass of all reactants.error: That ignores stoichiometry and limiting reagents.
the mass of all reactants.fix: Theoretical yield is calculated from the LIMITING reagent using mole ratios.
the mass of all reactants.action: Find limiting reagent → use mole ratio → calculate maximum product.

100% of the products.error: This is circular and doesn't define what theoretical yield means.
100% of the products.fix: Theoretical yield is the calculated maximum based on stoichiometry of the reaction.
100% of the products.action: Calculate theoretical yield BEFORE doing the experiment using mole ratios.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the difference between theoretical and actual yield.
persistent.action: Practice: calculate theoretical yield from stoichiometry, then compare to given actual yield.

actual_yield.name: Actual Yield
actual_yield.correct: Actual yield is the amount of product actually obtained from a reaction, measured experimentally.

the calculated amount from stoichiometry.error: That's theoretical yield, not actual yield.
the calculated amount from stoichiometry.fix: Actual = what you MEASURE. Theoretical = what you CALCULATE.
the calculated amount from stoichiometry.action: After running an experiment, you weigh or measure the product. That's actual yield.

always equal to theoretical yield.error: Actual yield is almost always less than theoretical yield.
always equal to theoretical yield.fix: Side reactions, incomplete reactions, and purification losses reduce actual yield.
always equal to theoretical yield.action: List reasons yield < 100%: equilibrium, side reactions, mechanical loss, purification.

the mass of limiting reagent.error: That's a reactant mass, not product yield.
the mass of limiting reagent.fix: Actual yield is the PRODUCT obtained, not the reactant used.
the mass of limiting reagent.action: Yield refers to product. Limiting reagent is a reactant.

persistent.gap: You're confusing reactants with products in yield calculations.
persistent.action: Always identify: limiting reagent (reactant) → theoretical yield (product) → actual yield (product).

yield_less_than_100.name: Why Yield < 100%
yield_less_than_100.correct: Yield is typically less than 100% due to: reactions reaching equilibrium before completion, side reactions forming by-products, and mechanical losses during purification.

atoms are lost in the reaction.error: Atoms are conserved. Mass is conserved.
atoms are lost in the reaction.fix: Atoms aren't lost, but they may end up in by-products or unreacted starting material.
atoms are lost in the reaction.action: Conservation of mass still applies. Low yield means atoms went somewhere else, not that they vanished.

the reaction runs out of energy.fix: Equilibrium, side reactions, and losses determine yield. Energy affects rate, not final yield.
the reaction runs out of energy.action: Think about WHERE the atoms go, not about energy running out.

the formula is wrong.error: The balanced equation is correct; yield depends on experimental factors.
the formula is wrong.fix: Equations show what CAN happen. Yield measures what DOES happen under real conditions.
the formula is wrong.action: Equations are theoretical. Reality includes equilibrium and losses.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why actual yield differs from theoretical yield.
persistent.action: List 5 reasons for low yield: equilibrium, side reactions, transfer losses, purification losses, incomplete reaction.

atom_economy_definition.name: Atom Economy Definition
atom_economy_definition.formula: % atom economy = (molar mass of desired product / molar mass of all reactants) × 100
atom_economy_definition.correct: Atom economy measures the percentage of atoms in reactants that end up in the desired product, indicating efficiency of atom utilisation.

percentage yield.error: Atom economy and yield are different measures.
percentage yield.fix: Atom economy = theoretical efficiency of the EQUATION. Yield = practical efficiency of the EXPERIMENT.
percentage yield.action: Atom economy is calculated from the equation. Yield is measured from the experiment.

the number of atoms in the product.error: It's a ratio, not just a count.
the number of atoms in the product.fix: Atom economy is the PERCENTAGE of reactant atoms that become the desired product.
the number of atoms in the product.action: Calculate: (mass of desired product / mass of all reactants) × 100.

reaction rate.error: Rate is speed. Atom economy is efficiency.
reaction rate.fix: Atom economy tells you what fraction of atoms become useful product, regardless of speed.
reaction rate.action: A slow reaction can have 100% atom economy. Speed ≠ efficiency.

persistent.gap: You're confusing atom economy with other measures of reaction efficiency.
persistent.action: Atom economy = equation efficiency. Yield = experimental efficiency. Rate = speed. Different concepts.

atom_economy_formula.name: Atom Economy Formula
atom_economy_formula.formula: % AE = (M of desired product / M of all reactants) × 100
atom_economy_formula.correct: Percentage atom economy equals the molar mass of desired product divided by the total molar mass of all reactants, times 100.

actual yield divided by theoretical yiel.fix: Atom economy uses MOLAR MASSES from the equation. Yield uses ACTUAL vs THEORETICAL amounts.
actual yield divided by theoretical yiel.action: Atom economy: molar masses from equation. Yield: measured vs calculated amounts.

mass of products divided by mass of reac.error: Close, but it's DESIRED product, not all products.
mass of products divided by mass of reac.fix: Atom economy focuses on the DESIRED product only. By-products don't count as useful.
mass of products divided by mass of reac.action: Identify the desired product. Only its molar mass goes in the numerator.

number of atoms in products divided by a.error: Use molar masses, not atom counts.
number of atoms in products divided by a.fix: The formula uses molar masses: M(desired product) / M(all reactants) × 100.
number of atoms in products divided by a.action: Molar mass accounts for atom masses. Just counting atoms ignores mass differences.

persistent.gap: You don't know the correct atom economy formula.
persistent.action: Memorise: % AE = [M(desired product) / M(all reactants)] × 100. Practice with 5 reactions.

high_atom_economy.name: High Atom Economy Reactions
high_atom_economy.correct: Addition reactions typically have 100% atom economy because all reactant atoms end up in the single product with no by-products.

substitution reactions.error: Substitution reactions produce by-products, lowering atom economy.
substitution reactions.fix: Substitution: A-B + C → A-C + B. The leaving group B is a by-product.
substitution reactions.action: Compare: addition (A + B → AB, 100% AE) vs substitution (A-X + Y → A-Y + X, <100% AE).

elimination reactions.error: Elimination produces small molecules as by-products.
elimination reactions.fix: Elimination removes atoms (often as H₂O or HX), reducing atom economy.
elimination reactions.action: Elimination: atoms LEAVE the product. Addition: atoms JOIN the product.

combustion reactions.error: Combustion produces CO₂ and H₂O, which are usually waste products.
combustion reactions.fix: Unless CO₂ and H₂O are your desired products, combustion has low atom economy.
combustion reactions.action: In combustion, the desired product is usually energy, not the chemical products.

persistent.gap: You can't identify which reaction types have high atom economy.

low_atom_economy.name: Low Atom Economy Reactions
low_atom_economy.correct: Substitution and elimination reactions have lower atom economy because they produce by-products (leaving groups or small molecules).

addition reactions.error: Addition reactions have HIGH atom economy.
addition reactions.fix: Addition: all atoms from reactants join into one product. No by-products = high AE.
addition reactions.action: A + B → AB means 100% of atoms go into product.

reactions with catalysts.error: Catalysts don't affect atom economy because they're regenerated.
reactions with catalysts.fix: Catalysts are unchanged and not included in atom economy calculations.
reactions with catalysts.action: Catalysts aren't reactants or products. They don't appear in atom economy calculations.

exothermic reactions.error: Energy release doesn't determine atom economy.
exothermic reactions.fix: Atom economy depends on what products form, not on energy changes.
exothermic reactions.action: Atom economy is about atoms, not energy. Exothermic or endothermic doesn't matter.

persistent.gap: You're confusing atom economy with other reaction characteristics.
persistent.action: Focus only on: how many reactant atoms end up in the DESIRED product?

multi_step_yield.name: Multi-Step Percentage Yield
multi_step_yield.correct: For multi-step pathways, multiply the individual percentage yields (as decimals) to get the overall percentage yield.

add the individual yields.fix: Each step reduces the total. 80% of 80% = 64%, not 160%.
add the individual yields.action: Think: each step loses some product. Losses compound multiplicatively.

average the individual yields.error: Averaging doesn't account for compounding losses.
average the individual yields.action: Try: 3 steps at 50% each. Multiply: 0.5 × 0.5 × 0.5 = 12.5%, not 50%.

take the lowest yield.error: All steps contribute to the overall loss.
take the lowest yield.fix: Every step reduces yield. Even high-yielding steps matter.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how yields combine in multi-step syntheses.
persistent.action: Practice: convert percentages to decimals, multiply, convert back. Do 5 examples.

multi_step_atom_economy.name: Multi-Step Atom Economy
multi_step_atom_economy.formula: % AE = M(final product) / M(all reactants in all steps) × 100
multi_step_atom_economy.correct: For multi-step pathways, atom economy is calculated using the molar mass of the final product divided by the total molar mass of all reactants added across all steps.

multiply individual atom economies.error: That's how you calculate multi-step YIELD, not atom economy.
multiply individual atom economies.fix: Atom economy uses total molar masses. Add reactant masses, don't multiply percentages.
multiply individual atom economies.action: Yield: multiply percentages. Atom economy: divide molar masses.

add individual atom economies.fix: Use total molar mass of final product / total molar mass of ALL reactants added.
add individual atom economies.action: Identify all reactants added at each step. Sum their molar masses. Divide.

only consider the final step.error: All steps contribute reactants to the overall pathway.
only consider the final step.fix: Include all reactants from all steps in the denominator.
only consider the final step.action: Track all atoms entering the pathway. How many end up in final product?

persistent.gap: You're confusing multi-step yield and atom economy calculations.
persistent.action: Yield: multiply fractions. Atom economy: total final product mass / total all reactants mass.

industrial_advantages.name: Advantages of High Atom Economy
industrial_advantages.formula: Less waste, lower cost, more sustainable
industrial_advantages.correct: High atom economy means less waste, lower disposal costs, more efficient use of raw materials, and reduced environmental impact.

faster reactions.error: Atom economy doesn't affect reaction speed.
faster reactions.fix: Atom economy is about EFFICIENCY of atom use, not speed. Catalysts affect speed.
faster reactions.action: High AE = less waste. Fast reaction = high rate. Different things.

higher yield.error: Atom economy and yield are independent.
higher yield.fix: High atom economy doesn't guarantee high yield. They measure different things.
higher yield.action: A reaction can have 100% AE but 50% yield, or 50% AE but 90% yield.

lower activation energy.error: Activation energy affects rate, not atom economy.
lower activation energy.fix: Atom economy is determined by the equation, not by energy barriers.
lower activation energy.action: Activation energy: kinetics. Atom economy: stoichiometry. Separate concepts.

persistent.gap: You're conflating atom economy benefits with other reaction improvements.
persistent.action: High atom economy benefits: less waste, cheaper materials, greener chemistry. Focus on atoms.

d7.tooltip: A + B → AB means all atoms are in the product

A single {{d3}} step in a pathway can drastically reduce the overall percentage yield of the entire synthesis.

d3.tooltip: The weakest link affects the whole chain

d5.tooltip: Every reactant added at any step counts

sentences.text: When calculating multi-step atom economy, do not double-count the main organic compound that {{d6}} from step to step.

advantages.title: Industrial Advantages of High Atom Economy

sentences.text: Reactions with high atom economy produce {{d1}} by-products, resulting in {{d2}} waste that needs to be disposed of.

d1.tooltip: More atoms in product = fewer in waste

d2.tooltip: Less waste is a major industrial benefit

sentences.text: High atom economy reduces the {{d3}} associated with waste treatment and disposal.
Developing high atom economy processes is a key principle of {{d4}}, which aims to reduce environmental impact.
High atom economy means more efficient use of {{d5}}, which is both economically and {{d6}} beneficial.
When 45 g of ethanol was oxidised, 38 g of ethanoic acid was obtained. To find percentage yield, divide {{d1}} by the {{d2}} calculated from stoichiometry.
